articles.headline: Delays, More Masks and Mandatory Shots: Virus Surge Disrupts Office-Return Plans
articles.snippet: A wave of the contagious Delta variant is causing companies to reconsider when they will require employees to return, and what health requirements should be in place when they do.
articles.abstract: A wave of the contagious Delta variant is causing companies to reconsider when they will require employees to return, and what health requirements should be in place when they do.
articles.lead_paragraph: Several hospital systems that previously held off making vaccines mandatory for health care workers are now willing to do so. Google employees in California who have voluntarily returned to the office are again wearing masks indoors. Goldman Sachs is considering whether to reinstitute testing for fully vaccinated employees in the company’s New York City offices, according to a person familiar with the situation who spoke on the condition of anonymity because nothing had been decided. And on Monday, Apple told its work force that it would push back its return-to-office date from September to October.
articles.byline: By Lauren Hirsch and Kellen Browning

articles.headline: For Republicans, Deep Wounds Fuel Resistance to Bolstering the I.R.S.
articles.snippet: A desire to crack down on tax cheats is overshadowed by years of G.O.P. resentment toward the agency.
articles.abstract: A desire to crack down on tax cheats is overshadowed by years of G.O.P. resentment toward the agency.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A plan by Democrats to pay for infrastructure investments by beefing up the Internal Revenue Service to catch tax evaders has resurfaced old resentments for Republicans, whose distrust of the agency has simmered for years, erasing hopes of a bipartisan legislative accord built on narrowing the so-called tax gap.

articles.headline: U.S. Strikes Taliban Targets in a Show of Force in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: The airstrikes showed American willingness to back up beleaguered Afghan government forces as the Taliban advance, but the extent of that willingness remains unclear.
articles.abstract: The airstrikes showed American willingness to back up beleaguered Afghan government forces as the Taliban advance, but the extent of that willingness remains unclear.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — U.S. military aircraft struck a number of Taliban positions this week in support of faltering Afghan government forces, in one of the first significant American reactions to the insurgents’ blistering advance across Afghanistan as U.S. troops withdraw.
articles.byline: By Adam Nossiter and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Biden Officials Now Expect Vulnerable Americans to Need Booster Shots
articles.snippet: The growing consensus that at least some Americans will need a booster is partly tied to research suggesting that Pfizer’s vaccine is less effective after about six months.
articles.abstract: The growing consensus that at least some Americans will need a booster is partly tied to research suggesting that Pfizer’s vaccine is less effective after about six months.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Biden administration health officials increasingly think that vulnerable populations will need booster shots even as research continues into how long the coronavirus vaccines remain effective.

articles.headline: They Waited, They Worried, They Stalled. This Week, They Got the Shot.
articles.snippet: The U.S. vaccine rollout has plateaued and the course of the coronavirus pandemic in this country may depend on how many people are ultimately swayed to get vaccinated.
articles.abstract: The U.S. vaccine rollout has plateaued and the course of the coronavirus pandemic in this country may depend on how many people are ultimately swayed to get vaccinated.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — They acknowledged that they could have shown up months ago. Many were satisfied that they were finally doing the right thing. A few grumbled that they had little choice.

articles.headline: The Most Influential Spreader of Coronavirus Misinformation Online
articles.snippet: Researchers and regulators say Joseph Mercola, an osteopathic physician, creates and profits from misleading claims about Covid-19 vaccines.
articles.abstract: Researchers and regulators say Joseph Mercola, an osteopathic physician, creates and profits from misleading claims about Covid-19 vaccines.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The article that appeared online on Feb. 9 began with a seemingly innocuous question about the legal definition of vaccines. Then over its next 3,400 words, it declared coronavirus vaccines were “a medical fraud” and said the injections did not prevent infections, provide immunity or stop transmission of the disease.

articles.headline: Biden’s Antitrust Team Signals a Big Swing at Corporate Titans
articles.snippet: The president has stacked his administration with crusaders who have spent their careers challenging corporate consolidation.
articles.abstract: The president has stacked his administration with crusaders who have spent their careers challenging corporate consolidation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden has assembled the most aggressive antitrust team in decades, stacking his administration with three legal crusaders as it prepares to take on corporate consolidation and market power with efforts that could include blocking mergers and breaking up big companies.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Cecilia Kang

articles.headline: Camps Have Been Scrambling for Counselors. Some Have Even Closed.
articles.snippet: Summer camps have reopened into a tight labor market without the international seasonal workers they often depend on.
articles.abstract: Summer camps have reopened into a tight labor market without the international seasonal workers they often depend on.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Joseph Charnock, like many parents, drew a sigh of relief when he dropped his 12-year-old daughter off for an eight-week session at Camp Quinebarge, on the shores of Lake Winnipesaukee in New Hampshire.

articles.headline: The Fisherwomen, Chevron and the Leaking Pipe
articles.snippet: Big Oil has a filthy legacy in the Niger Delta region of Nigeria. One prominent environmentalist said: “They are moving out and leaving all the mess behind.”
articles.abstract: Big Oil has a filthy legacy in the Niger Delta region of Nigeria. One prominent environmentalist said: “They are moving out and leaving all the mess behind.”
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Ruth Maclean and Yagazie Emezi

articles.headline: The Pandemic Ruined Third Grade. Can Summer School Make Up for It?
articles.snippet: After months of remote learning, Zion Graham is in summer school. But can a six-week program make up for his lost year?
articles.abstract: After months of remote learning, Zion Graham is in summer school. But can a six-week program make up for his lost year?
articles.lead_paragraph: GREENSBORO, N.C. — In second grade, Zion Graham bounded to school. He loved math. His favorite book was about a slow turtle who took all day to get dressed.

articles.headline: Bob Moses, Crusader for Civil Rights and Math Education, Dies at 86
articles.snippet: Mr. Moses developed a reputation for extraordinary calm in the face of violence as he helped to register thousands of voters and trained a generation of activists in Mississippi in the early 1960s.
articles.abstract: Mr. Moses developed a reputation for extraordinary calm in the face of violence as he helped to register thousands of voters and trained a generation of activists in Mississippi in the early 1960s.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bob Moses, a soft-spoken pioneer of the civil rights movement who faced relentless intimidation and brutal violence to register Black voters in Mississippi in the 1960s, and who later started a national organization devoted to teaching math as a means to a more equal society, died on Sunday at his home in Hollywood, Fla. He was 86.
articles.byline: By Michael Levenson, Clay Risen and Eduardo Medina

articles.headline: In Louisiana, Vaccine Misinformation Has Public Health Workers Feeling ‘Stuck’
articles.snippet: Facing deep mistrust stoked by rampant conspiracy theories, local health officials are fighting for influence when the only sure strategy for beating back the virus is getting more people vaccinated.
articles.abstract: Facing deep mistrust stoked by rampant conspiracy theories, local health officials are fighting for influence when the only sure strategy for beating back the virus is getting more people vaccinated.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHREVEPORT, La. — Dr. Martha Whyte, the top public health official in the northwest corner of Louisiana, was sitting at the back of a City Council meeting here on a muggy day recently when she was called to the front of the room to respond to an attack on the coronavirus vaccine.

articles.headline: Why Top Democrats Are Listening to Eric Adams Right Now
articles.snippet: Some prominent Democrats think their party’s nominee for mayor of New York offers a template for how to address issues of public safety.
articles.abstract: Some prominent Democrats think their party’s nominee for mayor of New York offers a template for how to address issues of public safety.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Eric Adams won New York City’s Democratic mayoral primary, his supporters in Congress were bombarded with questions about him from colleagues representing districts in Michigan and Florida, Chicago and Los Angeles.

articles.headline: Rookie Bankers Sour on Wall Street’s Pitch of Big Pay and Long Hours
articles.snippet: As young professionals re-examine their work-life balance, investment banking is becoming a less popular choice despite the money.
articles.abstract: As young professionals re-examine their work-life balance, investment banking is becoming a less popular choice despite the money.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Vince Iyoriobhe joined Bank of America’s investment banking division as a rookie analyst in 2017, he planned to stick around just long enough to get the experience needed to pursue his dream career in another corner of finance entirely — private equity.
articles.byline: By Kate Kelly and Lananh Nguyen

articles.headline: QR Codes Are Here to Stay. So Is the Tracking They Allow.
articles.snippet: Fueled by a desire for touchless transactions, QR codes popped up everywhere in the pandemic. Businesses don’t want to give them up.
articles.abstract: Fueled by a desire for touchless transactions, QR codes popped up everywhere in the pandemic. Businesses don’t want to give them up.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When people enter Teeth, a bar in San Francisco’s Mission neighborhood, the bouncer gives them options. They can order food and drinks at the bar, he says, or they can order via a QR code.

articles.headline: As China Boomed, It Didn’t Take Climate Change Into Account. Now It Must.
articles.snippet: China’s breathtaking economic growth created cities ill-equipped to face extreme weather. Last week’s dramatic floods showed that much will have to change.
articles.abstract: China’s breathtaking economic growth created cities ill-equipped to face extreme weather. Last week’s dramatic floods showed that much will have to change.
articles.lead_paragraph: China’s breakneck growth over the last four decades erected soaring cities where there had been hamlets and farmland. The cities lured factories, and the factories lured workers. The boom lifted hundreds of millions of people out of the poverty and rural hardship they once faced.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers, Keith Bradsher and Chris Buckley

articles.headline: Tunisia’s Democracy Verges on Collapse as President Moves to Take Control
articles.snippet: The effort by President Kais Saied threatened the only democracy to emerge from the Arab Spring protests a decade ago, and his opponents called it a coup.
articles.abstract: The effort by President Kais Saied threatened the only democracy to emerge from the Arab Spring protests a decade ago, and his opponents called it a coup.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Tunisia’s fledgling democracy, the only one remaining from the popular revolutions that swept the Arab world a decade ago, trembled on the brink of collapse Monday after its president sought to seize power from the rest of the government in what his political opponents denounced as a coup.

articles.headline: As Cyberattacks Surge, Security Start-Ups Reap the Rewards
articles.snippet: Investors have poured $12.2 billion into cybersecurity companies so far this year, nearly $2 billion more than the total for all of 2020.
articles.abstract: Investors have poured $12.2 billion into cybersecurity companies so far this year, nearly $2 billion more than the total for all of 2020.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As cyberattacks proliferated this year, Sanjay Beri, the chief executive of Netskope, a cloud security start-up, got a phone call. Then an email. Then more messages.

articles.headline: Return to Office Hits a Snag: Young Resisters
articles.snippet: A generation gap has emerged between them and colleagues who value the workplace over the advantages of remote work. Bridging it may require flexibility.
articles.abstract: A generation gap has emerged between them and colleagues who value the workplace over the advantages of remote work. Bridging it may require flexibility.
articles.lead_paragraph: David Gross, an executive at a New York-based advertising agency, convened the troops over Zoom this month to deliver a message he and his fellow partners were eager to share: It was time to think about coming back to the office.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Coral Murphy Marcos
